Deficiency Narrative: During the inspection, it was observed that a mayonnaise was not proplery stored in the refrigerator. The mayonnaise was later thrown away.
Several rooms of the operatin had markings on doors and the walls, Broken electrical coverings and  broken blind, Dirty clothes on the floor were visible in closets.
the affidaviatis for 3 employees did not have the complete information if good cause for refusal of employment.
There are no evacuation plans posted to the rooms or entrance/exit areas.
Two children in care left the placement due to a lack of supervision.
Correction Narrative: Four children were interviewed regarding supervision and there were no concerns. The children expressed always being supervised when needed and that staff are always present. A corrective action plan was provided and states the following: All staff have been verbally reminded of their responsibility to maintain active supervision and awareness of each child's activities at all times. Staff will ensure that children are always within sight or sound and will document activities in the communication log at every transition.  All staff will receive a supervision training refresher.

Deficiency Narrative: Residents were denied snacks as discipline.
Correction Narrative: Residents were denied snacks as discipline.

Deficiency Narrative: It was found that staff members were using inappropriate language and making inappropriate comments towards children in care.
Staff were observed making facial expressions, pinching their nose, and spraying around a child with poor hygiene.
Correction Narrative:
Plan of Action:

1.Immediate Staff Counseling & Accountability:
The staff members involved will receive immediate coaching and corrective feedback regarding professional behavior and sensitivity towards children in care.
A written warning will be issued to the employees involved, emphasizing the importance of maintaining professionalism and respect.

2.Training & Reinforcement:
All staff was required to attend mandatory training on 2/24/2025:
Professionalism and appropriate conduct in a childcare setting
Trauma-informed care and empathy training
Addressing hygiene concerns with sensitivity and respect
Training was completed on 2/14/2025, and attendance records will be maintained in employee files.

3.Revised Hygiene Support Plan for Children:
Staff will receive guidance on how to compassionately assist children with hygiene concerns, including:
Private discussions to encourage self-care
Offering appropriate hygiene products discreetly
Creating a supportive and non-judgmental environment for personal care
Staff will be prohibited from making gestures, comments, or actions that could embarrass or demean a child.

4.Supervision & Monitoring:
The House Manager and shift supervisors will conduct random observations to ensure staff are demonstrating professional behavior at all times.
Any future incidents of inappropriate conduct will result in progressive disciplinary action, up to and including termination.

5.Positive Culture Reinforcement:
Team meetings will include discussions on fostering a respectful and supportive environment for all children.
Staff will be encouraged to model appropriate hygiene behaviors and assist children in a way that maintains dignity and self-esteem.

Deficiency Narrative: An employee was arrested on 2/9/25, and the incident was not reported to licensing as required.
Correction Narrative:
Plan of Action:

1.Immediate Reporting Compliance:
All arrest will be reported to the Texas Department of Family and Protective Services (DFPS) Licensing Division immediately upon discovery.
Going forward, all employee arrests, indictments, or criminal complaints will be reported within the required timeframe per licensing regulations.

2.Staff Training & Policy Reinforcement:
All administrative staff, supervisors, case manager and direct care staff received training on incident reporting requirements, focusing on:
Recognizing incidents requiring reporting to licensing
Proper documentation and communication protocols
Licensing timelines and compliance expectations
Training was completed by [2/18/2025] and signed acknowledgment forms will be kept in employee files.

3.Incident Reporting Procedure Implementation:
A written policy outlining the required reporting process for employee arrests and law enforcement involvement will be distributed to all staff.
The policy will specify that:
-Any staff member arrested, indicted, or facing a criminal complaint must notify management immediately.
-Management will be responsible for documenting and reporting the incident to licensing within the required timeframe.

4.Accountability & Monitoring:
Failure to report an arrest will result in progressive disciplinary action, up to and including termination.
The Administrator or House Manager will audit personnel records quarterly to verify compliance with reporting requirements.

5.Prevention Strategies:
During new employee orientation, staff will be informed of their obligation to self-report any arrest or criminal involvement.
Regular compliance reminders will be provided to staff through meetings and written notices.

Deficiency Narrative: The physical altercation between two employees that was observed by children in care was not reported to licensing as required.
Correction Narrative:
Plan of Action:
1.Immediate Reporting Compliance:
Incidents will be reported to the Texas Department of Family and Protective Services (DFPS) Licensing Division immediately upon discovery.
A designated staff member will be responsible for ensuring timely reporting of all serious incidents within the required timeframe.

2.Staff Training & Policy Reinforcement:
All staff member received retraining on incident reporting requirements, including HRC 42.063(a), to ensure full compliance on 2/24/2025.
Training covered:
-Recognizing reportable incidents
-Proper documentation procedures
-Timelines for reporting to licensing
Training was completed on [2/24/2025], and attendance records will be maintained in employee files.

3. Incident Reporting Procedure Implementation:
Written policy outlining the reporting process was distributed to all employees.
All incidents involving child safety, staff misconduct, or policy violations must be reported immediately to management and documented in an internal incident log.
Management will review all incidents within 24 hours to determine if they meet the criteria for reporting to licensing.

4.Accountability & Monitoring:
Any staff member found failing to report serious incidents will be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including termination.
The House Manager or designated supervisor will conduct random audits of incident reports to ensure compliance with licensing requirements.
The Administrator will verify that all serious incidents are reported as required.

5.Prevention Strategies:
All staff members involved in the altercation was immediately terminated.
Conflict resolution training will be provided to all employees to prevent future altercations.
Staff will be reminded of the professional conduct policy and expectations for workplace behavior.
A zero-tolerance policy for workplace violence will be strictly enforced.

Correction Narrative: The operation submitted a corrective action plan via email on 2-3-25. The operation will implement a verification system requiring all participants to sign and confirm their involvement in the Service Plan review to meet the services required for the children in care.

Correction Narrative: The operation submitted a corrective action plan via email on 2-3-25. The operation will ensure all admission documentation includes chronic health conditions and conduct a thorough review during intake.

The operation submitted a corrective action plan via email on 2-3-25. The operation will Ensure high-risk behaviors are assessed and documented upon admission. The operation will re-train staff on identifying and recording high-risk behaviors.
The previous safety plan has been revised to include accurate information.

Deficiency Narrative: The Preliminary Service Plan does not include all the immediate needs specifically documented for each child.

12/20/2024- received the following from operation: case manager will undergo mandatory training on proper documentation procedures, including the importance of ensuring accurate, true, and complete records for each child.
Schedule periodic audits of service plans and case files to identify and correct errors before they can impact care or compliance.
Per operation an AR will not be requested.
